segments.pli: Saṃyutta Nikāya 46
segments.en: Linked Discourses 46

segments.pli: 1. Pabbatavagga
segments.en: 1. Mountains

segments.pli: 6. Kuṇḍaliyasutta
segments.en: 6. Kuṇḍaliya

segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sākete viharati añjanavane migadāye.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāketa in the deer part at the Añjana Wood.

segments.pli: Atha kho kuṇḍaliyo paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
segments.en: Then the wanderer Kuṇḍaliya went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

segments.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho kuṇḍaliyo paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

segments.pli: “ahamasmi, bho gotama, ārāmanissayī parisāvacaro.
segments.en: “Master Gotama, I like to hang around the monasteries and visit the assemblies.

segments.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bho gotama, pacchābhattaṃ bhuttapātarāsassa ayamācāro hoti—
segments.en: When I’ve finished breakfast, it’s my habit to

segments.pli: ārāmena ārāmaṃ uyyānena uyyānaṃ anucaṅkamāmi anuvicarāmi.
segments.en: wander from monastery to monastery, from park to park.

segments.pli: So tattha passāmi eke samaṇabrāhmaṇe itivādappamokkhānisaṃsañceva kathaṃ kathente upārambhānisaṃsañca:
segments.en: There I see some ascetics and brahmins speaking for the sake of winning debates and finding fault.

segments.pli: ‘bhavaṃ pana gotamo kimānisaṃso viharatī’”ti?
segments.en: But what benefit does Master Gotama live for?”

segments.pli: “Vijjāvimuttiphalānisaṃso kho, kuṇḍaliya, tathāgato viharatī”ti.
segments.en: “The benefit the Realized One lives for, Kuṇḍaliya, is the fruit of knowledge and freedom.”

segments.pli: “Katame pana, bho gotama, dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā vijjāvimuttiṃ paripūrentī”ti?
segments.en: “But what things must be developed and cultivated in order to fulfill knowledge and freedom?”

segments.pli: “Satta kho, kuṇḍaliya, bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā bahulīkatā vijjāvimuttiṃ paripūrentī”ti.
segments.en: “The seven awakening factors.”

segments.pli: “Katame pana, bho gotama, dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satta bojjhaṅge paripūrentī”ti?
segments.en: “But what things must be developed and cultivated in order to fulfill the seven awakening factors?”

segments.pli: “Cattāro kho, kuṇḍaliya, satipaṭṭhānā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satta bojjhaṅge paripūrentī”ti.
segments.en: “The four kinds of mindfulness meditation.”

segments.pli: “Katame pana, bho gotama, dhammā bhāvitā, bahulīkatā cattāro satipaṭṭhāne paripūrentī”ti?
segments.en: “But what things must be developed and cultivated in order to fulfill the four kinds of mindfulness meditation?”

segments.pli: “Tīṇi kho, kuṇḍaliya, sucaritāni bhāvitāni bahulīkatāni cattāro satipaṭṭhāne paripūrentī”ti.
segments.en: “The three kinds of good conduct.”

segments.pli: “Katame pana, bho gotama, dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā tīṇi sucaritāni paripūrentī”ti?
segments.en: “But what things must be developed and cultivated in order to fulfill the three kinds of good conduct?”

segments.pli: “Indriyasaṃvaro kho, kuṇḍaliya, bhāvito bahulīkato tīṇi sucaritāni paripūretīti.
segments.en: “Sense restraint.

segments.pli: Kathaṃ bhāvito ca, kuṇḍaliya, indriyasaṃvaro kathaṃ bahulīkato tīṇi sucaritāni paripūretīti?
segments.en: And Kuṇḍaliya, how is sense restraint developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the three kinds of good conduct?

segments.pli: Idha, kuṇḍaliya, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā manāpaṃ nābhijjhati nābhihaṃsati, na rāgaṃ janeti.
segments.en: A mendicant sees an agreeable sight with their eye. They don’t desire it or enjoy it, and they don’t give rise to greed.

segments.pli: Tassa ṭhito ca kāyo hoti, ṭhitaṃ cittaṃ ajjhattaṃ susaṇṭhitaṃ suvimuttaṃ.
segments.en: Their mind and body are steady internally, well settled and well freed.

segments.pli: Cakkhunā kho paneva rūpaṃ disvā amanāpaṃ na maṅku hoti appatiṭṭhitacitto adīnamānaso abyāpannacetaso.
segments.en: But if they see a disagreeable sight they’re not dismayed; their mind isn’t hardened, dejected, or full of ill will.

segments.pli: Tassa ṭhito ca kāyo hoti ṭhitaṃ cittaṃ ajjhattaṃ susaṇṭhitaṃ suvimuttaṃ.
segments.en: Their mind and body are steady internally, well settled and well freed.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, kuṇḍaliya, bhikkhu sotena saddaṃ sutvā … pe …
segments.en: Furthermore, a mendicant hears an agreeable sound with the ear …

segments.pli: ghānena gandhaṃ ghāyitvā … pe …
segments.en: smells an agreeable odor with the nose …

segments.pli: jivhāya rasaṃ sāyitvā … pe …
segments.en: tastes an agreeable flavor with the tongue …

segments.pli: kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṃ phusitvā … pe …
segments.en: feels an agreeable touch with the body …

segments.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya manāpaṃ nābhijjhati nābhihaṃsati, na rāgaṃ janeti.
segments.en: knows an agreeable thought with their mind. They don’t desire it or enjoy it, and they don’t give rise to greed.

segments.pli: Tassa ṭhito ca kāyo hoti, ṭhitaṃ cittaṃ ajjhattaṃ susaṇṭhitaṃ suvimuttaṃ.
segments.en: Their mind and body are steady internally, well settled and well freed.

segments.pli: Manasā kho paneva dhammaṃ viññāya amanāpaṃ na maṅku hoti appatiṭṭhitacitto adīnamānaso abyāpannacetaso.
segments.en: But if they know a disagreeable thought they’re not dismayed; their mind isn’t hardened, dejected, or full of ill will.

segments.pli: Tassa ṭhito ca kāyo hoti, ṭhitaṃ cittaṃ ajjhattaṃ susaṇṭhitaṃ suvimuttaṃ.
segments.en: Their mind and body are steady internally, well settled and well freed.

segments.pli: Yato kho, kuṇḍaliya, bhikkhuno cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā manāpāmanāpesu rūpesu ṭhito ca kāyo hoti, ṭhitaṃ cittaṃ ajjhattaṃ susaṇṭhitaṃ suvimuttaṃ.
segments.en: When a mendicant’s mind and body are steady internally, they’re well settled and well freed when it comes to both agreeable and disagreeable sights,

segments.pli: Sotena saddaṃ sutvā … pe …
segments.en: sounds,

segments.pli: ghānena gandhaṃ ghāyitvā … pe …
segments.en: smells,

segments.pli: jivhāya rasaṃ sāyitvā … pe …
segments.en: tastes,

segments.pli: kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṃ phusitvā … pe …
segments.en: touches,

segments.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya manāpāmanāpesu dhammesu ṭhito ca kāyo hoti, ṭhitaṃ cittaṃ ajjhattaṃ susaṇṭhitaṃ suvimuttaṃ.
segments.en: and thoughts.

segments.pli: Evaṃ bhāvito kho, kuṇḍaliya, indriyasaṃvaro evaṃ bahulīkato tīṇi sucaritāni paripūreti.
segments.en: That’s how sense restraint is developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the three kinds of good conduct.

segments.pli: Kathaṃ bhāvitāni ca, kuṇḍaliya, tīṇi sucaritāni kathaṃ bahulīkatāni cattāro satipaṭṭhāne paripūrenti?
segments.en: And how are the three kinds of good conduct developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the four kinds of mindfulness meditation?

segments.pli: Idha, kuṇḍaliya, bhikkhu kāyaduccaritaṃ pahāya kāyasucaritaṃ bhāveti, vacīduccaritaṃ pahāya vacīsucaritaṃ bhāveti, manoduccaritaṃ pahāya manosucaritaṃ bhāveti.
segments.en: A mendicant gives up bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and develops good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.

segments.pli: Evaṃ bhāvitāni kho, kuṇḍaliya, tīṇi sucaritāni evaṃ bahulīkatāni cattāro satipaṭṭhāne paripūrenti.
segments.en: That’s how the three kinds of good conduct are developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

segments.pli: Kathaṃ bhāvitā ca, kuṇḍaliya, cattāro satipaṭṭhānā kathaṃ bahulīkatā satta bojjhaṅge paripūrenti?
segments.en: And how are the four kinds of mindfulness meditation developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the seven awakening factors?

segments.pli: Idha, kuṇḍaliya, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
segments.en: A mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

segments.pli: vedanāsu … pe …
segments.en: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

segments.pli: citte … pe …
segments.en: mind …

segments.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
segments.en: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

segments.pli: Evaṃ bhāvitā kho, kuṇḍaliya, cattāro satipaṭṭhānā evaṃ bahulīkatā satta bojjhaṅge paripūrenti.
segments.en: That’s how the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the seven awakening factors.

segments.pli: Kathaṃ bhāvitā ca, kuṇḍaliya, satta bojjhaṅgā kathaṃ bahulīkatā vijjāvimuttiṃ paripūrenti?
segments.en: And how are the seven awakening factors developed and cultivated so as to fulfill knowledge and freedom?

segments.pli: Idha, kuṇḍaliya, bhikkhu satisambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ … pe … upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.
segments.en: A mendicant develops the awakening factors of mindfulness, investigation of principles, energy, rapture, tranquility, immersion, and equanimity, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.

segments.pli: Evaṃ bhāvitā kho, kuṇḍaliya, satta bojjhaṅgā evaṃ bahulīkatā vijjāvimuttiṃ paripūrentī”ti.
segments.en: That’s how the seven awakening factors are developed and cultivated so as to fulfill knowledge and freedom.”

segments.pli: Evaṃ vutte, kuṇḍaliyo paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: When he said this, the wanderer Kuṇḍaliya said to the Buddha,

segments.pli: “abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama, abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama.
segments.en: “Excellent, Master Gotama! Excellent!

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evameva bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
segments.en: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, Master Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.

segments.pli: Esāhaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
segments.en: I go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

segments.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
segments.en: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

segments.pli: Chaṭṭhaṃ.

sections.title: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāketa…

suttaplex.blurb: The wanderer Kuṇḍaliya points out that some ascetics argue for the sake of winning debates. But the Buddha says his path is for the sake of liberation. Kuṇḍaliya asks what leads to liberation, and the Buddha traces a sequence of conditions back to sense restraint.
